title: Did William Shakespeare win any awards for his productions? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mark is right, but to expand on that a little bit.. Early Modern English playing (not acting yet) was not the glamorous profession that we imagine actors have today. Players went to work every day, rehearsed (a little), did the business of running a theatre (the 8 men who owned Shakespeare's theatre, including the playwright himself, were also the principle actors), and put on a show at 2 in the afternoon. Every day. What we might now call an honest day's work. There weren't Oscars, Tonys, or anything like that. Shakespeare's company had the patronage of the Lord Chamberlain, and later the King himself. There are also limited records of court performances of plays in the early years of King James I's reign, and those records show a considerable amount of performances of plays by Shakespeare - Othello, Merchant of Venice, The Winter's Tale, etc.Finally, Shakespeare himself had earned patronage as a poet, although his last long poem was published before the Lord Chamberlain's Men were formed, so that may not have continued.

Winning awards for productions would be a totally alien concept to an Elizabethan playwright. You’d gauge success based on how many performances you gave, how many seasons you could continue to revive the play, and how long it remained in active repertoire. There was a kind of sideways game — fighting to stop bootleg productions of his work by other companies. There is one recorded honor and it’s actually an impressive one for the time. He (along with a couple other members of his company) was given special cloth by royal proclamation to be fashioned into a fine suit to be worn in the Queen’s procession at a special time one year. That’s about as impressive as it gets for his time and profession.

In 1996, Hamlet was nominated for an Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay. Kenneth Brannagh, the nominee, said he felt a little odd about this as his film was, famously, the first movie ever made of the whole script of Hamlet and therefore the nominee for writing the script should have been Shakespeare. However, Mr Shakespeare did not win. The movie won a couple of other award, but not in the writing category. Hamlet (1996 film) - Wikipedia

None that I am aware of during his life. Playwrights were not generally well thought of in literary circles; poetry was considered the higher literature. I suppose the finest "award" was the First Folio that his friends and actors assembled from their own copies of his work. However, that was more of a gift to the human race than anything else.

Well,the closest any Renaissance writer could come to an “award” was to have financial recognition through patronage. This Shakespeare accomplished twice, first when his acting troupe was honored with the patronage of the Lord Chamberlain, then later, with the patronage of King James I. In recognition of this patronage, Shakespeare’s troupe was known first as “The Lord Chamberlain’s Men”, then as “The King’s Men.” Both carried a great deal of influence. Any other concept of “award” is a Hollywood creation. thank you
He and his family were granted a coat of arms.

William “BillyBoy” Shakespeare won the Tony for Best Musical in 1645 for the original production of OKLAHOMA! Not only was this his first win for Book and Libretto, but he won as a performer for the role of Much Ado Annie. The song “Poor Judd Is Daid (Woe Nonny Nonny)” was nominated for the 1645 Oscar ceremony, but lost to “Death Bed Scramble” from Ben Jonson’s VOLPONE!
Well, he was given his own coat of arms.[1] That has to be worth at least an Emmy.  Footnotes[1] Shakespeare part 2. Shakespeare among the Heralds | The Heraldry Society

Shakespeare wrote before there were Tonys, Oscars, BAFTAs, Grammies, etc., or even Pulitzer Prizes. But, his career won him the patronage of the King, the admiration of his peers and audience, and enough money to become a wealthy gentleman.
They didn’t hand out Oscars (or the equivalent) in Shakespeare’s day. He was rewarded by the only things that really mattered: commercial and critical success.
There weren’t any Oscars, Emmies or Tonies in his day. Actors and playwrights were trying to do good work and stay afloat financially, not to win trophies.

Shakespeare was granted the “Coat of Arms” after waiting for it for years. The rulers were as corrupt as the ones now we face. So, everything that Shakespeare deserved was not given to him. Read more from the following link. The facts about Shakespeare’s coat of arms

When I was in college, an English professor quipped that, given a choice between discovering an entirely new play by Shakespeare or discovering his laundry list, scholars would prefer to discover his laundry list, so little is known of Shakespeare’s life.
Every time an audience applauds, Shakespeare gets an award. He has likely received more awards than any author in the history of the world. What better award could there be?
